headline.main: F.D.A. Taking Cautious Path In Its Regulation of Tobacco

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration is charting delicate course following ruling by Federal Judge William S Osteen Sr that it can regulate nicotine as drug; former FDA Comr David A Kessler says 35 million to 45 million Americans are addicted to nicotine, and agency cannot experiment on people by making public policy without data; as scientists collect data that might bolster case for reducing or eliminating nicotine from cigarettes, agency is keeping watchful distance, focusing instead on how to negotiate political minefield of tobacco regulation (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When a Federal judge in North Carolina declared last week that the Food and Drug Administration could regulate nicotine as a drug, he opened the way for tobacco foes to realize a once-distant dream -- a world where cigarettes could be so radically altered that the whole country, in the words of one addiction expert, ''would become detoxified.'' But the Federal agency is not going to do that, at least not now.
